Classes are held three days a week; students complete the conversation group work independently of the classroom sessions.
71544.re: course 1 or Spanish Placement Examination score of 20.

71545.desc: Origins and development of international law: international law is examined both as a reflection of the present world order and as a basis for transformation. Topics include jurisdiction and sovereignty, treaties, use of force, commercial law, and human rights.
71545.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority enrollment period.

71546.desc: An introduction to the major areas, problems, and techniques of modern linguistics.

71547.desc: Close reading of short stories and some novels with the aim of developing critical methods for the analysis and interpretation of prose fiction. Topics include character, plot, narrative structure, and the poetics of prose.

71548.desc: The limit of a function, calculating limits, continuity, tangents, velocities, and other instantaneous rates of change. Derivatives, the chain rule, implicit differentiation, higher derivatives. Exponential functions, inverse functions, and their derivatives. The mean value theorem, monotonic functions, concavity, and points of inflection. Applied maximum and minimum problems. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and course 11A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A or Economics 11A.
71548.re: course 3 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3 or placement exam score of 40 or higher or AP Calculus AB exam score of 3 or higher. Prerequisite waived for non-UCSC students.

71549.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to oceanography focusing on biological, chemical, geological, and physical processes. Covers topics such as origins and structure of planet Earth and its oceans, co-evolution of Earth and life, plate tectonics, liquid water and the hydrologic and hydrothermal cycles, salinity and elemental cycles, ocean circulation, primary production and nutrient cycles, plankton and nekton, life on the sea floor, near shore and estuarine communities, future environmental problems our oceans face. Students may also enroll in and receive credit for Earth Sciences 1. (Note: General Education credit will not be granted for this course and Biology 80D.)

71550.desc: Study of philosophical movement called the Vienna Circle, named so chiefly for intellectual excellence of its members, but also for external historical reasons. Course pays careful attention to intercultural aspects of ideas of the Vienna Circle: intellectual climate under which these ideas were formed, how thoughts of its members found an echo outside of Austria, and how they made a lasting influence on philosophical thinking in England and in U.S.

71551.desc: An introduction to the main areas of philosophy using both classic and contemporary sources.  Focuses on central and enduring problems in philosophy such as skepticism about the external world, the mind-body problem, and the nature of morality.

71552.desc: Introduces the politics of gender in advanced capitalist and "developing" nations. Uses materials from political theory, comparative, and American politics. Examines the role of gender, gender-based movements, and sexual politics in political development and in contemporary political affairs.

71553.desc: Origins and development of international law: international law is examined both as a reflection of the present world order and as a basis for transformation. Topics include jurisdiction and sovereignty, treaties, use of force, commercial law, and human rights.
71553.re: Enrollment restricted to politics and Latin American and Latino studies/politics majors during priority enrollment period.

71554.desc: Examines basic theories, models, methods, and research findings in human memory. Both traditional and nontraditional topics are covered. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 130A.
71554.re: course 3. Prerequisite waived for non-UCSC students.

71555.desc: Focuses on contemporary research in the psychology of human emotions. Special attention given to work in cognitive science, including psychology, linguistics, philosophy, and anthropology, on how emotions are central to understanding human action and mental life.
71555.re: Enrollment restricted to psychology, linguistics, philosophy, and anthropology majors.

71556.desc: Examines how social class shapes attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors. Emphasis is placed on structural barriers and their impact on the well-being of low-income groups. Strategies for reducing classist discrimination and improving interclass relations are discussed.
71556.re: Enrollment restricted to anthropology, community studies, economics, legal studies, politics, psychology, sociology, or feminist studies majors.

71557.desc: With herbaria, live specimens, and field drawings as reference, students produce botanical images with both ink and watercolor. Basic plant morphology, dissection studies, and plant environments are introduced and integrated into illustration assignments. Appropriate for students with a demonstrated interest in science illustration through previous course work in science and art, or through extracurricular activity in the field, or a strong desire to learn the skills of the field. Enrollment process differs for Summer Session. May be repeated for credit.

71558.desc: Exploration of nature, structure, and functionings of American society. Explores the following: social institutions and economic structure; the successes, failures, and intractabilities of institutions; general and distinctive features of American society; specific problems such as race, sex, and other inequalities; urban-rural differences. Fulfills lower-division major requirement.

71559.desc: Historical and contemporary examination of urban life including community, race, geography, urban and suburban cultures and lifestyles, stratification, housing, crime, economic and environmental issues, demographic changes, and global urbanization.
71559.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.

71560.desc: Focuses on the interaction between family and society by considering the historical and social influences on family life and by examining how the family unit affects the social world. Readings draw on theory, history, and ethnographic materials.

71561.desc: Analysis of the current health care "crises" and exploration of the social relationships and formal organizations which constitute the medical institution. Study of the political, economic, and cultural factors which affect the recognition, distribution, and response to illness.

71562.desc: Why certain social acts are considered threatening and how individuals or groups become stigmatized. Sociological analysis of the institutions and processes of social control and the experience of becoming deviant and living with a stigmatized identity. Introductory course in sociology recommended.

71563.desc: Students work on developing resonance, range and expressivity for stage performance via physical exercises and text explorations undertaken in small groups. Prerequisite(s): course 20. Audition required for acceptance into class.

71565.desc: A writing course examining news and feature articles in popular print media. Students write their own articles and analyze how a particular content is mandated by conventional forms, by the structure of the industries, and by ideas of "newsworthiness." Designed for journalism minors and students for whom a course in media criticism is central to their program. Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements; qualifications determined by instructor at first class meeting.

71566.desc: Develops rhetorical facility in disciplinary writing for upper-division social science majors. Requires critical and disciplinary reading, writing in modes appropriate to social science disciplines, and a substantial research or critical paper within the student's own discipline.
71566.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.

71567.desc: Introductory level course in basic analysis of human remains for the medico-legal profession. Course covers development of the field of forensic anthropology, introduction to human osteology, how age, sex, ancestry, and stature are determined from skeletel material, and how skeletel trauma is evaluated. (Formerly

71568.desc: Focuses on discourse and practices of marketing, and its appropriations of sociology, psychology, and anthropology. Examines maps and models of the world discussed by marketers in order to understand how marketers attempt to build cultural movements around brands and products.

71569.desc: Provides a three-part overview of the historical development and key figures in medical anthropology. Explores early investigations in cross-cultural health practices and beliefs; examines the doctor/patient relationship, the co-creation of disease and accompanying theoretical approaches; and investigates post-structuralist approaches to medicine.

71570.desc: Examines the methodological and theoretical foundations for the archaeology of European colonization in North America and the post-colonial material world.

71571.desc: Uses popular films and documentaries to examine how age, mainly but not exclusively old age, is depicted in film and constructed more broadly with reference to the visibility, invisibility, and public expectations about old age.

71572.desc: Critically examines the politics of environmental problems, focusing on ways that science, discourse, economic systems, culture, race, gender, power, and development shape human-environment interactions through time. Explores responses to these contentious interactions through movements of environmental justice.

71573.desc: An introductory programming course for computer science and engineering majors where students learn programming and documentation skills, as well as algorithmic problem solving and programming methodologies. Introduces students to computers, compilers, and editors, and they are expected to write medium-sized programs. Topics include, but are not limited to, procedures and functions, conditionals and loop control structures, static and dynamic memory manipulations, and text processing. Prior experience with Unix helpful, and some prior programming experience strongly recommended (e.g., course 10). This course is required for computer engineering, computer science, electrical engineering, and information systems management majors.
71573.re: eligibility to enroll in Mathematics 19A (Mathematics 2B or 3 or 40 or higher on mathematics placement exam) or Mathematics 19A or 11A or Economics 11A or Applied Math and Statistics 11A. Concurrent enrollment in course 12L required.

71574.desc: Laboratory sequence complementing topics taught in course 12A by providing training and exposure to several software development tools and practices not covered in course 12A. In addition, the lab provides an initial exposure to a second programming language to reinforce concepts from course 12A.
71574.re: eligibility to enroll in Mathematics 19A (Mathematics 2B or 3 or 40 or higher on mathematics placement exam) or completion of Mathematics 11A or 19A or Economics 11A or AMS 11A.  Previous or concurrent enrollment in 12A required.

71575.desc: An introduction to the basic techniques of computer programming. Detailed study of one programming language. Extensive practice using a computer, particularly personal computers, to solve problems. Course 60G is intended for social sciences and humanities students. Students can only receive credit for either 60G or 60N.  Students cannot receive credit for course 60G if taken concurrently with or subsequently to course 12A.

71576.desc: Surveys the rapid development of genetic engineering science and biotechnology-based industries and examines the economic, health, environmental, legal, and social justice dimensions of new biotechnology applications: genetic screening, cloning, transgenic animals and crops, genetically engineered food, and biodiversity prospecting. Readings, lectures, World Wide Web site reviews, student presentations, and papers will address controversial choices faced now by scientists, farmers, doctors, consumers, public officials, and global governance agencies. Prerequisite(s): course 25 strongly recommended.

71577.desc: Survey of various approaches to feminist science studies. Explores the role of women in Western science, feminist critiques of scientific methods, the role of language in science, and the scientific construction of sexed bodies and racial identities.

71578.desc: Focuses on the construction and reproduction of gender and gendered relations in the region known as the "Middle East." Examines the dynamics of gender as played out through systems of masculinities, femininities, the body, religion, the state, and the nation.

71579.desc: Examines gender and sexuality in wartime and in militarized societies, women's positioning and organizing in different "war zones" as mothers, and warriors and traitors. Focuses on dilemmas of feminist peace politics, queer coalitions and transnational anti-war organizing, primarily in the Middle East, with particular emphasis on Palestine/Israel.
71579.re: Enrollment restricted to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.

71580.desc: Course globalizes colonial, early national, and antebellum U.S. history. Through a transnational perspective, it revisits U.S. history, taking a fresh look at the role of Native Americans, Africans, and Europeans in the Americas and their place in the emerging world economy. Course also aims to frame the history of laboras well as political and economic structuresin the U.S. within the parameter of world history.

71581.desc: Exploration of Jews during the British Colonial period up through the 20th century. Considers the impact of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Natural Rights theory on Jewish civil status in America; examines the emergence of the American Jewish community in the 20th century by studying anti-semitism in the 1930's, the impact of World War II, the Holocaust, the Cold War, and the establishment of the state of Israel on American Jewish culture and identity.

71582.desc: Examines feminist interpretations and critiques of East Asian women's statuses and gender inequality articulated by 20th-century activists and theorists, addressing a few major issues ranging from nationalism to war responsibilities to sexuality to political rights. Explores feminist movements in East Asia, the differences in the articulation of gender between countries and regions, as well as compares historical and transnational contexts that shape conceptualizations of feminisms.

71583.desc: Examines the history of American immigration from the arrival of the earliest European colonists through the major period of European immigration of the 19th century (16001860). Emphasizes racial and ethnic contact and conflict, religion, nativism and language, and cultural maintenance. Addresses issues of immigration, migration strategies, settlement patterns, assimilation, citizenship and national identity, race, and ethnicity.

71584.desc: Examines the idea of the Middle East in its various cultural and historical manifestations. Students engage with a broad range of interdisciplinary material including theory, history, film, fiction, and feminist scholarship.

71585.desc: Provides students with the conceptual tools for work in queer theory. Topics include histories of sexuality, transgender and transsexual theory and politics, queer theory's relation to feminist theory, homonormativity, and queer of color critique.

71586.desc: Traces the parallel emergence of science fiction religion and religious science fiction in 20th-century U.S., with special focus on humanist and post-humanist ethics. Case studies include intelligent design, Gaia theory, ecofeminism, afrofuturism, exotheology, and Golden Age science fiction.

71587.desc: Offers a systematic exploration of alternative conceptions of the nature of law, including positivism, natural law, formalism, realism, pragmatism, and theories of justice. Additional focus includes the nature of law, relation of law and morality, rights and other legal concepts.
71587.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority enrollment only.

71588.desc: An introduction to works (novels, film, autobiography, travel literature) considered in relation to life in the modern world system. Topics and contexts include colonialism, postcolonialism, transnational capitalism, migrancy, diaspora, global cities, travel, and tourism. Summer 2006: American regional literatures.

71589.desc: Examination of selected fiction written between the end of the 18th century and the Civil War, with attention to historical and cultural as well as literary issues. Summer 2006: "The Power of Blackness:" Poe, Hawthorne, and Melville. Satisfies the English and Modern Literary Studies concentrations. (Formerly American Literature 103A.)

71590.desc: Major poets since World War II, with attention to leading movements and critical issues. Summer 2006: The San Francisco Experiment: Writing and the Radical Imagination in the Bay Area. Satisfies the English and Modern Literary Studies concentrations; also satisfies the Poetry distribution requirement. (Formerly American Literature 104C.)

71591.desc: Examines the emergence of vernacular lyric poetry and its evolution in the troubadour, Italian, and English traditions, with particular emphasis on romantic love, figurations of gender, and nuances in lyric form. Satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern concentration; also satisfies the Poetry and the Pre- and Early Modern distribution requirements.

71592.desc: Studies in the theory of cultural studies. Summer 2006: Jose Rizal and James Joyce: anti-colonial nationalism in Ireland and Filipinas. Satisfies the Modern and World Literature concentrations; also satisfies the Global distribution requirement. May be repeated for credit.

71593.desc: Examination of individual authors or critical problems in ancient, medieval, or early modern/Renaissance literature. Summer 2006: phenomenon of comedy. Satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern Literature concentration; also satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern and Senior Seminar distribution requirements. May be repeated for credit.
71593.re: Literature 101. Enrollment restricted to senior literature majors.

71594.desc: A continuation of 6A. Wave motion in matter, including sound waves. Geometrical optics, interference and polarization, statics and dynamics of fluids. Introduction to thermodynamics, including temperature, heat, thermal conductivity, and kinetic energy.
71594.re: courses 5A/L or 6A/L and Mathematics 11A or 19A or 20A; concurrent enrollment in course 6M required. Corequisite: Mathematics 11B or 19B or 20B.

71595.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6B. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
71595.re: courses 5A/L or 6A/L; concurrent enrollment in course 6B required.

71596.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 6B. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
71596.re: courses 5A/L or 6A/L; concurrent enrollment in course 6B required.

71597.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 7B. One three-hour laboratory session per week.
71597.re: Concurrent enrollment in course 7B is required.

71598.desc: Introduces students to both mainstream theories of social movement, the critiques of these theories, and alternative ways of conceptualizing contemporary social movement and political action.

71599.desc: Senior seminar that focuses on identity development in adolescence and young adulthood. Discusses theory and research on the development of personal and social identities and the sociocultural contexts in which these personal and social identities are negotiated. Course satisfies seminar requirement.
71599.re: Course 102 strongly recommended. Enrollment restricted to senior psychology majors or by permission of instructor.

71600.desc: Introduces key concepts and debates around topics such as political economy, nationalism, globalization, citizenship, class, and social movements and addresses their importance to American studies. Examines these issues through attention to political theory, social transformations, and cultural representations.

71602.desc: Study of Netherlandish, German, and French art in the 15th and 16th century. Works of art will be examined in light of their social, political, and historical context. Artists to be studied include van Eyck, Drer, Bosch,  and Bruegel.

71603.desc: Interdisciplinary study of Las Vegascommunities, civic structures, and commercial industry. Explores the social, political, and economic forces which have inflected urban growth and design in Las Vegas from 19002000.

71604.desc: Developments in 19th- and 20th-century architecture, focusing on issues of modernity, technology, and industrialization, new building types, competitions, and urban growth as well as on major movements, buildings, and architects.

71605.desc: Explores the intersections of investigation, interpretation, and persuasion and hones strategies for writing and research. Students develop specific, practical ways of improving their writing through sustained critical thinking about diverse issues from multiple points of view. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 1.
71605.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and C1 requirements.

71606.desc: Explores the intersections of investigation, interpretation, and persuasion and hones strategies for writing and research. Students develop specific, practical ways of improving their writing through sustained critical thinking about diverse issues from multiple points of view. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 1.
71606.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and C1 requirements.

71607.desc: Explores the intersections of investigation, interpretation, and persuasion and hones strategies for writing and research. Students develop specific, practical ways of improving their writing through sustained critical thinking about diverse issues from multiple points of view. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 1.
71607.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and C1 requirements.

71608.desc: Explores the intersections of investigation, interpretation, and persuasion and hones strategies for writing and research. Students develop specific, practical ways of improving their writing through sustained critical thinking about diverse issues from multiple points of view. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 1.
71608.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and C1 requirements.

71609.desc: Explores the dynamics of written language: its relationships to speech, thought, and culture; its uses in different personal, academic, professional, and public contexts; its abuses in jargon and propaganda. Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing.
71609.re: Enrollment restricted to first-year students during priority enrollment; may be opened if space allows.

71610.desc: Explores the dynamics of written language: its relationships to speech, thought, and culture; its uses in different personal, academic, professional, and public contexts; its abuses in jargon and propaganda. Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing.
71610.re: Enrollment restricted to first-year students during priority enrollment; may be opened if space allows.

71611.desc: Explores the dynamics of written language: its relationships to speech, thought, and culture; its uses in different personal, academic, professional, and public contexts; its abuses in jargon and propaganda. Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing.
71611.re: Enrollment restricted to first-year students during priority enrollment; may be opened if space allows.

71612.desc: Explores the dynamics of written language: its relationships to speech, thought, and culture; its uses in different personal, academic, professional, and public contexts; its abuses in jargon and propaganda. Course work includes extensive practice in different kinds of writing.
71612.re: Enrollment restricted to first-year students during priority enrollment; may be opened if space allows.

71613.desc: Explores interdisciplinary methods, theories, and practices involved in producing and reproducing knowledges about "Africa" and the "West" within global politics. Examines ideas of international relations, international political economy, development, military structures, cultural formations, and the state through the critical use of film, literature, and scholarly texts.

71614.desc: Theory and practice of improvisation in the performing arts with an emphasis on acting improvisation techniques. Readings and films develop a theoretical and historical understanding of spontaneous invention on stage. Students attend area theater improvisational performances.

71616.desc: Introduces students to critical reading and interpretation of Shakespeare's plays as well as provides them with relevant context of the social conditions and practices of the Renaissance theater.

71617.desc: Juxtaposes Shakespeare's plays with sources Shakespeare may have adapted and adaptations that his works, in turn, have spawned. Explores Renaissance stage and printing practices and the processes of adapting for page and stage.

71618.desc: Offered online, the course explores major issues of interpretation of Shakespeare's classic play, which has occupied the minds of audiences, directors, designers, performers, and critics during its 400-year history. In doing this, it offers a sense of history of people's preoccupations with and thoughts about the play. Students taking this class are expected to complete the course during the quarter for which they are enrolled. All students enrolled in this course should visit elsinore.ucsc.edu and write to elsinore@ucsc.edu.

71619.desc: Uses writing to respond to Shakespeare Santa Cruz's summer productions. Requires frequent assignments, such as reviews, interviews, performance notes, comparisons of productions, background pieces, and reflective essays. Students regularly revise work in response to instructor and peer feedback.
71619.re: Satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71620.desc: Classical and newly developed molecular-genetic techniques used to explore genetic variation in wild populations of the fruit fly
71620.re: course 105; course 100 or Biochemistry and Molecular Biology 100A recommended. Enrollment restricted to biological sciences and affiliated majors, non-majors by permission of instructor.

71621.desc: Covers the basics of marine mammal taxonomy, anatomy, and field methods with an emphasis on local field identification and understanding of local species. Will include field trips to Long Marine Lab, Ano Nuevo, and Monterey Bay. Students are billed a materials fee.
71621.re: courses 20A, 20B, and 20C. Must be taken concurrently with course 139. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71622.desc: Explores several themes in Asian American history: immigration, exclusion, World War II as a watershed, family relations, political struggle and interethnic solidarity, and multiple identities.

71623.desc: Intensive instruction in elementary Italian language emphasizing oral fluency. Taken in conjunction with Italian 1B, the two courses are equivalent to levels 1-2-3.  Accelerated pace allows a rapid mastery of grammar and syntax, giving the student a basic knowledge of Italian in only two quarters.

71624.desc: Sequential to course 1A, completes the equivalent instruction offered through Italian 1-2-3. May not be taken by students who have completed Italian 1 or Italian 3.
71624.re: Open to students who have successfully completed either 1A or Italian 2; for students completing course 2, course 3 is preferable.

71625.desc: Topics in morphology, physiology, development, genetics, and endocrinology selected to exemplify current issues and perspectives in organismic biology.
71625.re: course 20A. Prerequisite waived for non-UCSC students.

71626.desc: Special studies in printmaking, as announced. Students are billed for a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
71626.re: course 26. Enrollment restricted to art and pre-art majors.

71627.desc: An introductory course to basic theories in American studies, including the U.S. in historical and transnational perspectives, social and cultural diversity and conflict in American life, and debates over concepts of national culture and citizenship.

71628.desc: Introduction to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict through different historical perspectives, leading to current political debates. Class materials will mainly focus on marginalized perspectives, attempting to allow for a more complex and diverse view of Palestinian and Israeli societies.

71629.desc: An introduction to the principles and practices of laboratory microbiology, with a substantial presentation of optical microscopy. Students are billed a materials fee.
71629.re: previous or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 119 is required. Enrollment restricted to biological sciences and affiliated majors, non-majors by permission of instructor.

71639.desc: Classical and newly developed molecular-genetic techniques used to explore genetic variation in wild populations of the fruit fly
71639.re: course 105; course 100 or Biochemistry and Molecular Biology 100A recommended. Enrollment restricted to biological sciences and affiliated majors, non-majors by permission of instructor.

71640.desc: Covers major theoretical issues arising in the study of resource allocation, the function of markets, consumer behavior, and the determination of price, output, and profits in competitive, monopolistic, and oligopolistic market structures. Also considers issues of welfare and public policy. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 100M.
71640.re: courses 1, 2 and 11A, or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A or Mathematics 19A or 21 or 22. Course 11B strongly recommended.

71641.desc: Designed as an introduction to comparative and historical sociology, this course focuses on the internationalization of national societies. After a review of classical liberalism, Marxism, Weberian, and world systems theories, transnational corporations, international regulatory agencies, and peasant revolutionary movements are analyzed from a global perspective. Fulfills lower-division major requirement.

71642.desc: Examines popular culture both as a social practice and social product: the ways that commercial cultural products are created, distributed, and circulated with contemporary American society and how they operate as expressions of social moods, conflicts, and identities and the multiple meanings and social significance of popular culture. Treats popular culture as a contemporary arena where major social and cultural struggles over power and meaning is played out in the areas of sexuality, identity, gender, social class, and race and ethnicity.
71642.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.

71643.desc: This course on special topics in ethnography will be taught on a rotating basis by various faculty members. Precise focus of each year's courses will vary according to the instructor and will be announced by the department. May be repeated for credit.

71644.desc: Explores current historical and theoretical writings on the lived experiences of Chicanas and Mexican American women in American history. Themes include domination/resistance politics, (re)presentations, contestation, social reproduction, identity and difference.

71645.desc: Introduction to photography as an art form that explores visual ideas beginning with camera-ready use, negative development, and printing. Prepares for further work in photography or for collaboration with other media in art including computer arts and two- and three-dimensional mixed media. Critically examines photographic works while reading historical and theoretical texts. Students are billed  a materials fee.
71645.re: Enrollment restricted to pre-art, art, and history of art and visual culture majors.

71646.desc: Familiarizes students with the basic concepts of educational research and facilitates progress toward completion of dissertation while identifying faculty and community resources available to assist in research.
71646.re: Enrollment restricted to Ed.D. graduate students.

71647.desc: Data collection in the field is required of all joint Ed.D. students for four quarters in the second year. Students are assigned to a faculty member who supervises data collection, liaises with district mentors, and conducts problem-solving seminars.
71647.re: Enrollment restricted to Ed.D. graduate students.

71649.desc: Provides students with intensive experience conducting current research in social psychology. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. May be repeated for credit.

71665.desc: Structured off-campus learning experience providing hands-on experience and pre-professional mentoring in a variety of health-related settings. Interns are trained and supervised by a professional at their placement and receive academic guidance from their faculty sponsor. Students spend 1012 hours per week at their placement, participate in weekly discussion meetings on campus, keep a reflective journal, and submit a final paper. Prerequisite(s): by interview with health sciences internship coordinator; applications are due one quarter in advance to the Health Sciences Internship Office. Enrollment restricted to health sciences majors. May be repeated for credit.

71668.desc: Open to declared majors only, this course combines fieldwork at an off-campus agency and a comprehensive analytical paper produced for the agency. Equivalent to a thesis in terms of the depth and quality of the work expected, it is combined with a 5-credit internship. Concurrent enrollment in course 183 required. Students submit petition to sponsoring agency. Enrollment restricted to environmental studies majors and the combined majors with Earth sciences, biology and economics.

71669.desc: Preparation of a senior thesis over one, two, or three quarters, beginning in any quarter.  When taken as a multiple-term course extending over two or three quarters, the grade and evaluation submitted for the final quarter apply to each of the previous quarters. Students contemplating a senior thesis should have a superior academic record and be well prepared with a suitable background of previous coursework or independent study for performing their proposed research. Students must file a petition with the Psychology Office the quarter in which they would like to begin the thesis. Senior thesis petitions are available in the Psychology Department Office. Check with office for enrollment conditions.
